sentence: Geopolitical issues such as the worsening economic crisis in Turkey spilled over into the U.S. markets Friday, pressuring numerous sectors including banking where the likes of Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) each suffered more than 1% declines.
At one point Friday the Turkish lira traded to a record low, falling as much as 20% against the U.S. dollar.
Economist believe President Trump’s authorized doubling of metals tariffs on the country was the main reason.
Seeking shelter, investors worry a global crisis could soon unfold.
The decline in equities means both the Dow and S&P 500 suffered losses for the week.
The latter snapped a five-week winning streak.
The Nasdaq Composite, meanwhile, managed 0.4% weekly gain.
"This is a classic, instinctive reaction in the market," said Quincy Krosby, chief market strategist at Prudential Financial, according to CNBC.
"Stocks are down while ... Treasuries are getting a bid."
Is there cause for concern for the week ahead?
Not according to the earnings results we’ve seen so far.
Overall, positive Q2 earnings results, combined with confident guidance, should drive the markets higher, even as trade rhetoric and geopolitics play out.
Here are four stocks to keep an eye on.
Wall Street expects Home Depot to earn $2.84 per share on revenue of $30.01 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings came to $2.25 per share on revenue of $28.11 billion.
What to Watch: Was the first quarter an aberration or a sign of things to come?
While Q1 adjusted EPS of $2.08 topped Street expectations of $2.05, Q1 revenue of $24.95 billion fell short of the $25.15 billion analysts were looking for.
Meanwhile, the company’s same-store sales growth (SSSG) of 4.2% also fell shy of analysts’ expectation of 5.4%, triggering a selloff in the stock.
On Tuesday Wall Street will look to see if the Home Depot’s improved merchandising, combined with its online strategy can lead to higher SSSG.
Wall Street expects Cisco to earn 68 cents per share on revenue of $12.77 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings came came to 61 cents per share on revenue of $12.13 billion.
What to Watch: The world’s largest maker of network equipment has beaten analysts’ earnings estimates in three of the last four quarters.
It has achieved this feat as it tries to develop growth businesses within services such as security, the cloud, data center and analytics, which remain massive opportunities for the company.
At the same time, the company is carefully scaling back mature switching and routing business which have become saturated.
On Wednesday Wall Street will want to see the extent to which progress has been made in these areas.
Wall Street expects Walmart to earn $1.22 per share on revenue of $126.04 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings came came to $1.08 per share on revenue of $123.36 billion.
What to Watch: Can Walmart finally get out of its funk?
Shares — currently trading at $89 — have fallen about 20% from its 52-week high since February.
Investors have grown concerned the company’s once-promising e-commerce capabilities may actually be no match for Amazon (AMZN), which has grown to account for 5% of all U.S. retail spending.
On Thursday Walmart not only must outline the strength of its e-commerce business, it must also address ways to get profit margins growing again.
Wall Street expects Nvidia to earn $1.66 per share on revenue of $3.11 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings came to 92 cents per share on revenue of $2.23 billion.
What to Watch: Shares of the graphic chip powerhouse, which has delivered ten consecutive beat-and-raise quarters, have risen some 35% year to date, compared to a 6% rise in the S&P 500 index.
Ahead of Thursday’s results, Goldman Sachs analyst Toshiya Hari, citing datacenter revenue and strong gross margins from Nvidia, sees an additional 26% return on the horizon.
"Nvidia, in our view, is one of the few companies in our semiconductor coverage with exposure to multiple secularly growing end-markets (i.e.
PC Gaming, Datacenter, ADAS/AV), a deep and sustainable competitive moat, and as a result, a margin/return profile that significantly exceeds its peers," wrote Hari.

To the extent Hari’s prospects comes to fruition, along with Nvidia’s capabilities in the areas of artificial intelligence and cryptocurrency mining, Nvidia stock could finally reach $300 in the weeks following the report.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
